webTitle: Eurotunnel claims compensation for migrant disruption

fields.bodyText: A concrete wall six metres high and 600 metres long is needed to prevent refugees and migrants from entering the Channel tunnel at Calais, according to Eurotunnel. The company is asking the British and French governments to foot the €6m (£4.6m) bill for the work, as well as reimbursing €29m (£23m) in lost revenue and costs from last year. Eurotunnel said it expected even more migrants to attempt to reach the UK this summer, and has called for a joint control centre linking police, border guards and security staff to be implemented swiftly in preparation. The operator of the tunnel linking the UK with France said disruption at Calais affected its truck and passenger shuttle services in the second half of 2015. Announcing its annual results, it said: “The security of the fixed link being the responsibility of the two governments, a claim for €29m has been made via the intergovernmental commission to compensate essentially the revenue losses due to migrant pressure.” The chief executive, Jacques Gounon, said the Treaty of Canterbury made the states’ obligations clear, but said Eurotunnel was still shouldering additional costs for what was a question of public security. He said that while measures taken by Britain and France had meant there had been no disruption or breaches since late October last year, “I regret that when I asked for reaction in the first half [of 2015] I could not persuade the state that action was needed.” He said he expected the governments to “find a suitable gentleman’s agreement” over the compensation bill, adding: “What is important that it is a long-term relationship and what happened before the state reaction is absolutely clear. Traffic in January and February has shown that it is not an issue now.” But, he added, both governments needed to do more and spend more to maintain the tunnel’s security: “There is a risk of course: we know that millions of migrants could overwhelm Europe this summer and some could go to Calais. We want the funding to be one step in advance of any new migrant invasion. “I would not like to be in the same position [this year] … It would be better to anticipate a new invasion of migrants this summer. This is a long term issue and we need to be prepared.” The concrete wall would extend the mouth of the tunnel 600m further into France along the Eurostar tracks, which have been identified as a potential weak spot to breach the tunnel security. Eurotunnel carries Eurostar high-speed trains between Paris, Brussels and London, and shuttle trains containing passenger cars, coaches and freight trucks. The company suffered disruption to its services starting in the summer from refugees and migrants, 6,000 of whom now live in the makeshift camps outside Calais known as the Jungle. webTitle: The infrastructure plan sounds great. But what to build and how to fund it? | Greg Jericho

fields.bodyText: The Australian Infrastructure Plan released on Wednesday contains a broad outlook over the next 15 years, which offers attractive views on how Australia might look in 2031. But it also contains much that will be as politically difficult to implement as was the failed attempt to increase the GST. How quickly things change. Last year in May when Tony Abbott released Infrastructure Australia’s (IA) audit report he began his speech by boasting: “You have got a prime minister for infrastructure here today, you have got a deputy prime minister for infrastructure, and you have got minister Briggs as well.” Now we have a prime minister who doesn’t badge himself with the dopey tag of “infrastructure prime minister”, the deputy PM is now the minister for agriculture, and minister Briggs is just a cautionary tale. But what doesn’t change is politicians’ love of infrastructure. “There is nothing better than to see big yellow things pushing dirt around. It is marvellous,” said Barnaby Joyce on Wednesday. Since the Liberal party has come into power there has however been a fall in the sightings of those big yellow things: But there are signs that a change has occurred with the past two quarters showing an increase in the amount of engineering work yet to be done on roads, bridges, rail and harbours: So there is work in the pipeline, even if the level of investment remains only around 2007 levels. But more is not always better, which is where Infrastructure Australia comes in – its plan outlines the framework for infrastructure development and funding and also a priority list of projects. The overriding factor of the IA plan is Australia’s population. Coming as it did in the same week Australia’s population passed 24 million, the report notes by 2031 Australia’s population should have reached 30 million. Overwhelmingly, the growth will occur in Sydney, Melbourne, Brisbane and Perth. The report notes that in the next 15 years, these cities will “collectively need to accommodate 5.9 million more people”. This leads to two main issues: where to put those people in a manner which continues our way of life (within certain parameters); and how to ensure our economy copes with that growth to ensure the 30 million people continue to enjoy growing living standards. On the first issue, IA recommends more “medium to high-density development within established urban areas” but it also notes this alone is not enough. Sounding a bit like a time-share brochure, it argues that this higher density housing must also offer “high-quality design” be “well-connected by infrastructure to jobs and education”, and also provide “access to high-quality public spaces, including parks, community facilities and cultural precincts”. How to achieve this? Well the report comes in two parts – the infrastructure plan, and its latest “priority list”. In some ways the priority list is the more sexy of the two (well, as sexy as these things can get) as it contains the list of actual projects to be undertaken. The overall plan is more philosophical in nature and outlines how things must change in order to achieve this wonderful future that has “high-frequency, interconnected public transport systems” that move people about “efficiently and comfortably”. The priority list gets the headlines because the aspects are more concrete (literally). For example, the list includes the now shelved Melbourne East West Link. This project, which was halted by the election of the Andrews Labor government in Victoria, is rated by IA as one of the “high priority initiatives”. But we should be a bit careful of overselling what that means. There are 30 such projects listed and eight of those are in Victoria. IA does note of the East West Link that the annual cost of delays due to the congestion along Melbourne’s east-west corridor is $73m, and by 2031 the cost will increase to $144m. The cost is no surprise as it was identified last year in IA’s audit report. But it does not actually mean IA is recommending the project proposed by the former Victorian Liberal government and supported by Tony Abbott. Importantly, IA rates the next stage of the project as “initiative development” – ie start thinking about what you want to do and then come up with a business case. Given the previous East West Link project was rated at having a return of just 45 cents for every dollar invested, that suggests there is a ways to go before that project will commence. The overall IA plan, while more abstract in nature, also sets out some fairly headline-grabbing points, mostly around funding. When releasing the plan, Malcolm Turnbull suggested that “there is plenty of money around, both in the private markets and in the general infrastructure investment world”, which is Turnbull-speak for avoiding saying “public funds”. While the report does recommend governments take advantage of the very low levels of interest to pay for infrastructure with borrowings, it has an overall sharp focus on private sector funding – especially user-pays. It recommends a user-pays system for roads – arguing the current “system is unfair because the link between usage and charging is weak”. The report notes that our roads are paid through a mix of taxes such as the fuel excise (46%), registration fees (20%), licence fees (2%), stamp duty (10%) and a top-up from other taxes for the remaining 22%. The report argues that the fuel excise is inefficient – especially as car makers are moving to make cars more fuel efficient – and the registration fee has no link with the level of use of roads. It recommends dispensing with such charges over 10 years and moving to purely user pays. There are, of course, already user-pay roads – tolls for motorways and tunnels and bridges – but this would be of a level thus far unseen in Australia. And given IA is effectively recommending in-car monitoring of travel, motorists would have to be happy with the government knowing where you are every time you go for a drive. Given such tolls would also be the purview of state governments to levy, any moves by the federal government to reduce fuel excise in order to push towards this model would see a massive bunfight of a GST level. It would also require public transport to be a lot better, but under the IA plan, that too would become more expensive. IA argues that only around 20% of the costs of public transport come from users – the rest is from general taxation. It argues greater cost recovery should come from users, and costs should be lowered via increased competition, arguing, “all public transport operators in Australia should be routinely and periodically exposed to a competitive process”. Greater competition via privatisation is also something it recommends for the NBN. It argues that in the “medium term” the NBN should be split up, either along technology or geographic lines, and sold. It also argues that the NBN will “materially improve service levels and the ability of households in rural and remote regions to connect to their wider social networks”, so it might be wise to wait till that actually occurs before finding a bidder. The 200-page report and its 73 recommendations offer some nice opportunities for governments and also a few traps – little wonder Turnbull was using the traditional kick-the-can-down-the-road response of saying “we will look at it carefully” and repeatedly promising the importance of a “a fair go”. Because while everyone likes to see “big yellow things”, there is much less agreement on how they should be paid for, and who should own the infrastructure they produce.
